channel.title: Why Aren't Web Documents Compiled?
channel.description:
Hey guys. I'm not a web developer by [b]any[/b] means. Hell, I can barely make an HTML document that displays text! But I do know that standard web documents and php files and such are sent as plain text. Why?
It confuses me because if HTML documents (we'll just use them as our primary example from now on) were compiled to byte code to be interpreted by the browser, not only would speed increase when constructing webpages, but their size would decrease and make viewing (especially on mobile devices) them much faster.
So help me out here. Give me the advantages that outweigh the pros I listed above, because I can't think of any other than easy source viewing.
~Lin

item.title: Why Aren't Web Documents Compiled?
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:7, topic:515424”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=633677.msg4280342#msg4280342 date=1365450879]
Since HTML has been covered, PHP actually has caching mechanisms which cache PHP opcodes/bytecode. Some popular ones are APC, XCache, etc.

en.wikipedia.org

PHP accelerator

A PHP accelerator is a PHP extension designed to improve the performance of software applications written in the PHP programming language. Most PHP accelerators work by caching the compiled opcode/bytecode of PHP representation of php files to avoid the overhead of parsing and compiling source code on each request (some or even most of which may never be executed). To further improve performance, the cached code is stored in shared memory and directly executed from there, minimizing the amount ...


[/quote]Yeah but that’s all server sided.[/quote]

Yes, exactly. He also asked about PHP scripts not just HTML.

Read full topic

Since HTML has been covered, PHP actually has caching mechanisms which cache PHP opcodes/bytecode. Some popular ones are APC, XCache, etc.

en.wikipedia.org

PHP accelerator

A PHP accelerator is a PHP extension designed to improve the performance of software applications written in the PHP programming language. Most PHP accelerators work by caching the compiled opcode/bytecode of PHP representation of php files to avoid the overhead of parsing and compiling source code on each request (some or even most of which may never be executed). To further improve performance, the cached code is stored in shared memory and directly executed from there, minimizing the amount ...

item.title: Why Aren't Web Documents Compiled?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:4, topic:515424”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=633677.msg4279993#msg4279993 date=1365396264]
Either way, a few website are just doing the entire thing in Javascript and CSS and then minifiying it, doing away with HTML completely.
[/quote]
This seems like the best approach. Use whatever custom format you want for building pages, and push the heavy lifting to the client[/quote]I don’t necessarily agree with it but there are some pros to it for sure.

Read full topic

item.title: Why Aren't Web Documents Compiled?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

RSCShadow:

Either way, a few website are just doing the entire thing in Javascript and CSS and then minifiying it, doing away with HTML completely.

This seems like the best approach. Use whatever custom format you want for building pages, and push the heavy lifting to the client

Read full topic

item.title: Why Aren't Web Documents Compiled?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

It’s too late at this point, really. Every browser vendor has come up with their own way to actually construct the DOM and run the Javascript. When HTML was designed, they had no idea it would become this popular.

Either way, a few website are just doing the entire thing in Javascript and CSS and then minifiying it, doing away with HTML completely.

Read full topic

item.title: Why Aren't Web Documents Compiled?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

For the same reason XML is not compiled. HTML is just a markup language. You could create a new file format to create webpages, but because HTML is the standard and easy to write people just decided to not do it.

Read full topic
